centralQuestion: Would overturning Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission (2010) improve the democratic process?

reasons.description: It would curb 'dark money' and improve transparency in elections by enabling stronger limits and disclosure for outside spending.

sources.title: The Guardian: 'Dark money: the quixotic quest to clean up US campaign financing'
Transparency International: 'Explainer: What is the FEC’s donor disclosure proposal and why does it matter?'

reasons.description: It would reduce the outsized influence of wealthy donors and special interests on policy, strengthening political equality and public trust.

sources.title: Freedom House: 'How Does U.S. Democracy Deteriorate?'

reasons.description: Overturning would align the law with broad public opinion that wants limits on campaign spending.

sources.title: Pew Research Center: '7 facts about Americans’ views of money in politics'

reasons.description: It would help prevent foreign-influenced or unaccountable corporate political spending by enabling stricter corporate governance and limits.

sources.title: Center for American Progress: 'Corporate Boards Must Be Responsible for Political Spending'

reasons.description: It would reverse what critics call judicial activism that undermined longstanding anti-corruption rules and legislative authority.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'Citizens United vs. Federal Election Commission is an Egregious Exercise of Judicial Activism'

objections.description: Political spending is protected speech; overturning would suppress First Amendment rights of associations, including corporations and unions.

sources.title: Stanford Hoover Institution: 'Corporations Are People, Too'

objections.description: The harms attributed to the ruling are overstated; the decision was not the 'disaster' critics predicted.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Citizens United gives freedom of speech back to the people'

objections.description: Overturning via constitutional amendment is impractical and misguided, risking broad restrictions on political speech.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: 'A Constitutional Amendment Overturning Citizens United—Really, How?'

objections.description: Citizens United did reshape campaign finance, but not in the way many critics envisioned; the effects are complex and not uniformly corrosive.

research.title: 'The Business of American Democracy: Citizens United, Independent Spending, and Elections' (Journal of Law and Economics, 2016)
research.description: Peer-reviewed study analyzing how Citizens United affected independent expenditures and electoral outcomes, using empirical data on spending and competition; the abstract details observed changes in independent spending after the ruling.

research.title: 'Corporate political spending and state tax policy: Evidence from Citizens United' (Journal of Public Economics, 2023)
research.description: Peer-reviewed article examining whether corporate political spending influenced state tax policy in the post-Citizens United environment; the abstract discusses identification strategy and findings on policy responsiveness.

research.title: 'The Impact of Citizens United on Large Corporations and Their Employees' (Political Research Quarterly, 2019)
research.description: Peer-reviewed study assessing how the ruling affected political activity by large firms and potential spillovers for employees; the abstract summarizes changes in corporate political engagement following Citizens United.

research.title: 'Anti-Democratic Influence: The Effect of Citizens United on State Legislative Agendas' (Legislative Studies Quarterly, 2024)
research.description: Peer-reviewed article investigating whether the ruling shifted state legislative priorities; the abstract outlines evidence that post-Citizens United agenda setting changed in ways linked to interest-group spending.
